*Spoiler Warning*

One could criticize this game's length, but that's hardly a problem. It contains fully fleshed out ideas and themes and condenses them into a 3-5 hour experience, one in which the first half misleads you into thinking this will be a normal game which will end after you beat all 19 tests. Features like GLaDOS growing more and more unreliable, the increasing suggestiveness of the narration, and the inclusion and eventual abundance of in-game objects which can kill you, the found storytelling is what speaks volumes and is the most impactful aspect to the first half, like how you can go outside the test chambers to see messages left on the walls from prior test subjects who warn you of GLaDOS or express suggestive love messages towards the companion cube. Seeing this, you question your initial preconceptions of the game and realize that what you thought was the apparent end isn't actually the end. Given that these rooms occur outside the test chambers and away from the main action, perhaps there's more to this environment than what you initially thought? Come to think of it, where are you, anyways, and how did you even get where you were in the first place? If you didn't think of these questions beforehand, they're now at the forefront of the game. These tests which were initially fun and challenging now dramatize the tension between you and GLaDOS. After the first half delivers its inevitable punchline, you escape to behind the test chamber walls, an area you only got to see a bit of beforehand. Certain areas in this section feel endless in their scope and the quality of this area looks unkempt and unfinished, as if you've escaped to somewhere you shouldn't be. Yet, this free will you think you have is merely an illusion as your path to the end is still linear like it was before. With this shift in tone, the identity of the game appears discarded, or is it still retained? Most of the mechanics you tested with in the first half are gone and the robotic voice which guided you through each test is mostly absent. Yet, the core mechanic of using a portal gun to move from one room to the next persists to the end. So, do you get to experience transcendence from the limitations of the game or is this transcendence just an illusion since an essence of what you interacted with in the first half is still present? It goes both ways. What's clear, to me, is that its narrative is a masterpiece of complex emotions and questions, conflicting or otherwise. While other puzzle games have replicated this story, none have ever been able to match its sublime quality. It reaches a grand and untouchable level with its art which neither Portal 2, any other puzzle game, or any other game ever made have ever been able to reach.

Portal um jogo de quebra-cabe√ßas, com vis√£o em primeira pessoa, com um conceito simples e Inovador.

ENREDO:
Voc√™ joga como Chell. Voc√™ acorda em um laborat√≥rio chamado APERTURE SCIENCE sem saber o que est√° acontecendo e voc√™ √© apenas guiado por um intelig√™ncia artificial chamada GlaDOS tendo que completar uma s√©rie de quebra-cabe√ßas (puzzles) com uma arma que cria portais (a Portal Gun).

GR√ÅFICOS:
S√£o bons.

JOGABILIDADE: 
Tem uma vis√£o em Primeira Pessoa. O jogo √© divido em fases, tendo cada fase um puzzle diferente, ficando dif√≠cil √† medida que que voc√™ completa as fases. O jogo introduziu a mec√¢nica inovadora de criar portais (apenas dois, sendo um azul e o outro laranja), assim te possibilitando resolv√™-los. A f√≠sica de objetos √© muito bem aplicada no jogo.
Essa mec√¢nica pode n√£o ser inovadora hoje em dia pois alguns jogos j√° usaram-a mas foi impressionante para a √©poca.

TRILHA SONORA:
N√£o √© nem ruim e nem boa, pode se dizer que se encaixa no clima, mesmo que na maioria do tempo seja monotona, mas d√° um clima de a√ß√£o quando √© pra dar. 
Lembra a trilha sonora de Half-Life.

TEMPO DE JOGATINA:
Infelizmente, Portal, √© um game bem curto eu consegui zerar ele em 2 dias, mas n√£o quer dizer que seja ruim, afinal √© melhor 4 horas de divers√£o do que 8 horas de enrola√ß√£o.

PRE√áO:
Acho que est√° barato, mas esperar por uma promo√ß√£o nunca √© demais.

BUGS: 
S√£o quase inexistentes, n√£o presenciei nenhum, pelo ou menos.

CONCLUS√ÉO:

 Um jogo √∫nico, muito bom (daqueles jogos do tipo "Se puder jogar, JOGUE!") ,com alguns puzzles desafiadores (n√£o todos). Recomendo esperar uma promo√ß√£o, mas n√£o significa que o pre√ßo original esteja caro.

I highly recomend this game especially on sale!

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Factor[/th]
        [th]Rating[/th]
	[th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay Loop[/td]
        [td]9[/td]
	[td]Really inventive gameplay loop. The game progressively increases the complexity of the puzzles, and you use the same tool that you get within the first minute - the portal gun, to overcome the gradually increasing challenge. I mean at this point, do I even need to describe the gameplay and say why it's so great? Everyone's played Portal and if you haven't - you got to.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Narrative[/td]
        [td]7[/td]
	[td]The narrative is very enigmatic, like what exactly is happening in the facility? The dialogue is humorous and keeps you entertained, while also building intrigue about the reality behind the situation. You just have to wait for the cake.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Visuals[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]I still don't believe how old this game is. The aesthetic design is so cleanly done that this game will always end up aging well and is a timeless classic. The aesthetic of the lab is clean, and the area that you end up in later (not going to delve into that much), is rugged and raw just like you'd expect. I would've appreciated some visual variety but overall, I still think the game looks really good.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mechanics[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]Excellently executed. The other main reason apart from the visuals that I think this game will age well whenever one decides to play it. It knows what it wants to do and does that masterfully.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Challenge[/td]
        [td]9[/td]
	[td]The game was a fair challenge and strikes a great balance in difficulty. The puzzles aren't too "difficult" or anything, but their progression in difficulty is very well done, and maybe outside of the very end bits, it never feels like it got stale.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Variety[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]The game knows what it wants to do and sticks with it. There aren't too many things that are done out of the box, especially mechanically. I remember one specific level where I was supposed to use momentum to jump from platform to platform using the portal gun in real-time. Something more along those lines could've been explored IMO. Something which required real-time use of the portal gun, or require the use of the physics more somehow. All in all, the diversity is still excellent and the game stays fresh all the way to the end. While the game looks great, some visual variety would've definitely felt even fresher. But it isn't that big a deal considering how short it is.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mapping[/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]Genius level design. I reserve the 10s for "WTF" level greatness, and the game pretty much nails it here. Every level is designed to feel completely unique compared to anything before it, and even the later levels after the facility, though hand-crafted, feel completely random and you actually feel like you're finding your way around things rather than having things already been designed for you. Just like Lester Freamon says, "All the pieces matter"[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Sound[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]The voice acting is superb. But I don't recall anything in terms of the music which was stayed with me or something. Probably purposeful.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Interface[/td]
        [td]8[/td]
	[td]Simple and does what it needs to do. The only aspect of the game which looks and feels a little dated IMO. But it definitely deserves a lot of credit for having pretty much zero HUD when you are in the game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Pricing & Performance[/td]
        [td]10[/td]
	[td]The game pretty much goes for free and only takes a couple hours to finish. This is a must play game if there ever was any.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Replay Value [/td]
        [td]-[/td]
	[td]Even though this game is pretty replayable, I don't judge puzzles games on their replay value. The only genre I do that with. [/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[b]SCORE : 8.6/10[/b]
